answers.answer: Hello,I'm sure this must be so scary for both of you.  It certainly sounds like he is having seizures.  Why I do not know. I too had a dog who had seizures he was diagnosed with Idiopathic Epilepsy.   The yelping before hand might make you wonder if there is something hurting him that could be causing the seizure, something inside him that the approaching seizure triggers causing him pain, or if it just his way of responding to the approaching seizure?  In Idiopathic Epilepsy the vocalizations prior to the seizure are said to be involuntary and not painful.http://www.canine-epilepsy-guardian-angels.com/CanineEpil.htmThe drinking afterward could possibly be diabetic related.  He definitely should be checked for canine diabetes and hypoglycemia.   Does he eat well during his meal times? Does his food contain sugar?  How many times a day do you feed him?   Is he drinking and peeing a lot ?My mom had a dog with diabetes.  Her diabetic dog would go nuts if her water bowel ever became empty.  She would bark and jump at things that were not there, and ram her head into walls etc.    Even on short road trips to McDonald's and back she required ice cubes or water to be present or the symptoms would start again.I Hope This Helps!   Good Luck To You and Your Little Guy.  God Bless Brenda

Your chi is definitely having seizures.  You'll need to have your vet examine him to determine WHY they're happening.  If no cause is evident, then it's called "idiopathic" epilepsy, which only means they don't know why these misfires happen in the brain.  Seizures can usually be well-controlled with medication like phenobarbitol, so make sure you talk to your vet about it.Our neighbor has a huge labrador retreiver who has had seizures most of his life.  His meds have had to be increased a couple times, but they're controlled to one event about every two to three months now.You need to be aware of hazards like pools and ponds with an epileptic dog.  If they seize in the water they'll likely drown.  Try not to panic when it happens.  Let the seizure run its course and keep your dog out of the way of things like furniture that may harm him.  It's very common for dogs and humans to vomit, defecate and/or urinate in the course of a seizure.  You'll want to make sure your dog doesn't breathe in stomach contents if he vomits.  Recovery time is always necessary and at least an hour is usually needed.  Some dogs may need the rest of the day to fully recovery.Keep a seizure diary and record the date, time of day, and anything else that might be going on that could act as a trigger.  My vet had one dog who seized only when the doorbell rang.  Disconnecting it solved the problem.  Go figure, right?!  Keeping a diary also helps your vet determine if and how much medication will be needed.
